Those who wish to hear the Dharma should have sixteen practices.
What are the sixteen?

First, one should listen at an appropriate time; second, one should listen attentively; third, one should listen with ears directed towards the speaker; fourth, one should listen with purpose; fifth, one should not criticize; sixth, one should not criticize mistakes; seventh, one should not seek out faults; eighth, one should respect the Dharma; ninth, one should respect the Dharma teacher; tenth, one should not belittle the Dharma; eleventh, one should not belittle the Dharma teacher; twelfth, one should not belittle oneself; thirteenth, one should be single-minded; fourteenth, one should not have other thoughts; fifteenth, one should maintain a focused mind; sixteenth, one should be fully aware of all thoughts and listen to the Dharma with right mindfulness.
If a virtuous one wishes to listen to the Dharma, one should listen to the Dharma in accordance with these sixteen practices.
What are the sixteen?

First, to be able to hear the Dharma at any time; second, to be able to hear the Dharma extensively; third, to listen with the ears to the Dharma that can be heard; fourth, to engage in what can be heard; fifth, not to be reproached for what can be heard; sixth, not to seek faults in what can be heard; seventh, to respect the Dharma and be able to hear it; eighth, to respect the expounder of the sÅ«tras and be able to hear it; ninth, not to change the Dharma and be able to hear it; tenth, not to change the expounder of the Dharma and be able to hear it; eleventh, not to change oneself and be able to hear it; twelfth, to be able to hear with a single-minded mind; thirteenth, to be able to hear without other thoughts; fourteenth, to be able to hear with a correct and upright mind; fifteenth, to be able to hear with a single intention for all; sixteenth, to be able to hear with a mind of mindfulness and concentration.
If a virtuous one wishes to hear the Dharma, they should follow these sixteen principles to be able to hear it.
Having heard the Dharma as explained above, one will then give rise to a trustworthy and agreeable mind, and from this one will reach the state of non-action.
Having heard such Dharma, one gives rise to the love of the wise and desires nothing, and thus attains non-action.
Having heard such Dharma, one gives rise to a joyful mind and love, and thus attains non-action.
Having heard such Dharma, one abandons evil attachments and attains a concentrated mind, and thus attains non-action.
Having heard such Dharma, one attains the abandonment of doubts and sees the light, and thus is led to non-action.

Having heard such Dharma, one sees the aggregates as nonexistent, sees the aggregates as empty, and sees the aggregates as light. By seeing, one attains liberation of the mind, purification of the mind, cessation of the mind, and liberation of the mind. Thus, one attains non-action.

Having heard the Dharma in this way, one sees the emptiness of all worldly practices, no longer dwells in them, and thus attains the cessation of love and extinction. One's mind turns to non-action, attains cessation of the mind, and attains liberation. Thus, one attains non-action.
Having heard the Dharma like this, one wishes to practice accordingly. Practicing alone and cutting off delusions, one attains the first aspiration and thus attains non-action.
Having heard the Dharma like this, one purifies the eyes and sees the Four Truths, and thus attains non-action.
Having heard the Dharma like this, one fulfills the practice and thus attains non-action.

Having heard the Dharma like this, the wise disciples of the Buddha do not trouble the speaker, they also attain joy from listening, they do not violate the teachings, they follow with ease, and they fulfill their own desires. These are the ten virtues that one should practice and attain.
What are the ten?

First, as a good friend; second, as a good precept; third, as a good fellow student; fourth, as one who understands the intention to receive; fifth, as one who receives the teaching; sixth, as one who asks; seventh, as one who hears the sutra; eighth, as one who expounds the sutra in a gathering; ninth, as one who becomes frightened due to the causes and conditions of fear; tenth, as one who is ashamed and frightened. Contemplating the original basis at this time is the original contemplation.

Then, one cuts off all evil dharmas. Having already been able to cut off from the original contemplation, one is able to counteract these dharmas, and then attains mastery of concentration, all due to the original contemplation. In this way, from the original truth, the disciple of the Way abandons the path.
Then, one may practice the ten contemplations.
What are the ten?

First, the thought of impurity, second, the thought of impermanence, third, the thought of suffering in impermanence, fourth, the thought of non-self in suffering, fifth, the thought of loathing food, sixth, the thought of disliking all under heaven, seventh, the thought of death, eighth, the thought of ignorance, ninth, the thought of turning away from intention, tenth, the thought of cessation.
The thought of impurity, virtuous ones!
Is in accordance with fourteen deviant dharmas.
What are the fourteen?

First, living together with the assembly with a lost mind; second, seeing greed in the assembly; third, hasty desire; fourth, impure thoughts and not knowing the meaning of practice; fifth, being unable to contemplate impurity; sixth, associating with people of evil conduct; seventh, not recognizing what is right; eighth, not serving; ninth, not asking; tenth, not guarding the faculties; eleventh, not knowing moderation in eating; twelfth, not engaging in practice in the first and last watches of the night; thirteenth, being unable to sit alone in meditation; fourteenth, being unable to contemplate impermanence.
Virtuous ones!
Those who follow the contemplation of impermanence, suffering, and no-self in the desires of the world follow six evil dharmas.
What are the six?

First, insufficiency; second, lack of diligence; third, lack of faith; fourth, desire; fifth, not wanting to sit in a secluded place; sixth, being unable to contemplate suffering and no-self as they are.
Thinking of the body as impure food is to not indulge in craving for flavors;
Thinking of all worldly pleasures as undesirable is to regard the myriad worldly affairs and desires as false;
Thinking of death is to follow the impermanence of life and illuminate thoughts.
Virtuous ones!
Following the eleven kinds of wrong refers to what?

First, doubt; second, lack of mindfulness; third, coarse body; fourth, sleepiness; fifth, excessive diligence; sixth, lack of diligence; seventh, false joy; eighth, fear; ninth, various thoughts; tenth, lack of reckoning; eleventh, mature contemplation of form.
Turning away from thoughts is to cause one to leave the path. Destroying thoughts means if the mind is in the Dharma, it causes one to leave the path.
This is what the virtuous ones!
Causes one to leave the path, not yet destroyed, to be destroyed, there are many of the three dharmas.
What are the three?
First, desire; second, cutting off; third, sitting practice.
The contemplation of impurity, Venerable Sirs!
Is practiced by fourteen dharmas.
What are the fourteen?

One, not living together with the assembly; two, restraining the mind; three, not seeing the assembly; four, guarding oneself; five, not desiring quickly; six, not following the contemplation of purity; seven, not observing the contemplation of purity; eight, not desiring to associate with worldly practitioners; nine, not desiring to accept worldly practices; ten, guarding the faculties; eleven, being content with food; twelve, practicing in the first and last watches of the night without sleep; thirteen, desiring to sit alone in disgust; fourteen, practicing the contemplation of impurity as if observing.
Venerable Sirs!

The disciple of the path has twenty factors that do not allow him to follow the path.
What are the twenty?

First, living together without practicing the Way; second, not asking; third, not knowing what is appropriate in one's practice; fourth, being dull; fifth, evil conduct; sixth, greedy thoughts; seventh, many affairs; eighth, little diligence; ninth, destroying one's refuge; tenth, form; eleventh, seeking pity; twelfth, inversion; thirteenth, losing one's mind; fourteenth, greed; fifteenth, living together with the unwholesome; sixteenth, not guarding the sense-doors; seventeenth, not knowing moderation in food and drink; eighteenth, not practicing in the first and last watches of the night; nineteenth, not delighting in solitary sitting and contemplation; twentieth, being like one who does not contemplate.
These twenty matters, O virtuous ones!
Cause one to depart from the Way.
For one who has not yet cut off desires and wishes to cut them off, there are eleven dharmas that are abundant. What are the eleven?

First, for desire; second, for attainment; third, for seeing convenience; fourth, for having a view; fifth, for having no waste; sixth, for victory; seventh, for attaining the characteristics of dharmas; eighth, for following; ninth, for questioning; tenth, for guarding oneself alone; eleventh, for observing as if existing.
Thus, it is already combined correctly.
Virtuous one!
The path disciples have many dharmas.

First, to live together in practicing the Way; second, to ask questions; third, to know what should be done in one's practice; fourth, to be free from confusion; fifth, to practice mutually; sixth, to be free from greed; seventh, to have few affairs; eighth, not to abandon diligence; ninth, to be free from misfortune; tenth, not to follow forms; eleventh, not to seek praise; twelfth, not to be inverted; thirteenth, to guard the mind; fourteenth, not to be greedy; fifteenth, to live well in a group; sixteenth, to guard the sense-doors; seventeenth, to be content with food and drink; eighteenth, to be able to practice in the first and last watches of the night; nineteenth, to delight in contemplating sitting alone; twentieth, to have insight.

First, one has already received an improper body; second, one has already created different karmic actions; third, one's life depends on others; fourth, until the end of one's life, one should seek clothing, food, medicine, and bedding; fifth, until the end of one's life, one's desires are already covered; sixth, until the end of one's life, one's human body desires pleasure. Having already followed these twenty causes, the mind is evil and becomes more evil, fearful and becomes more fearful, and turns away and becomes more distant. There are twenty kinds of practices that quickly stop the mind.
What are the twenty?
First, thinking of the mind, the mind quickly stops. Second, knowing the mind in the mind, the mind quickly stops. Third,
the mind is already one, the mind quickly stops. Fourth, correctly thinking and knowing the mind, the mind quickly stops. Fifth,
correctly stopping and thinking of the mind, the mind quickly stops. Sixth, thinking of the mind arising from correctness, the mind quickly stops. Seventh, collecting thoughts,
The eighth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the thought of assistance. The ninth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the thought of protection.
The tenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the practice of the four bases of mindfulness. The eleventh is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the four right efforts.
The twelfth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the four bases of supernatural power. The thirteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the avoidance of unwholesome thoughts.
The fourteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the practice of the proper conditions. The fifteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the study of the proper basis.
The sixteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the recitation and understanding of the scriptures. The seventeenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the thought of compassion.
The eighteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the joy of the many paths.
The nineteenth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the recognition of things. The twentieth is the swift cessation of thoughts due to the practice of this.
Thus, O Virtuous One!
The disciples of the Way should recognize the eleven obstacles.
What are the eleven?

First, gathering, second, overeating, third, many affairs, fourth, much talk, fifth, much sleep, sixth, delighting in group activities, seventh, enjoying living together, eighth, assisting in bodily pleasures, ninth, being light, tenth, greed for sex, eleventh, being unskillful in the countryside.
Dwelling in this, virtuous ones!
The calamities that have not been cut off should be cut off.
You should also study ten alternatives.
What are the ten?

First, the alternative of concentration, second, the alternative of concentration cessation, third, the alternative of concentration arising, fourth, the alternative of cessation, fifth, the alternative of restraint, sixth, the alternative of protection, seventh, the alternative of basis, eighth, the alternative of protecting calamities, ninth, the alternative of skillful means, tenth, the alternative of entering.
For one who enters in this way, the disciple of the Way has thirteen virtues. What are the thirteen?

First, for oneself, having remembered the TathÄgata, one immediately attains joy and faith, thus giving rise to joy. Second, for the Dharma, it is also like this. Third, for the practitioners, it is also like this. Fourth, for oneself upholding the precepts, it is also like this. Fifth, for others upholding the precepts, it is also like this. Sixth, for oneself attaining, it is also like this. Seventh, for others attaining, it is also like this. Eighth, for oneself giving, it is also like this. Ninth, for others giving, it is also like this. Tenth, for the path, there is much elimination of suffering. Eleventh, for the world, there is much expounding of the sÅ«tras to enable understanding. Twelfth, for turning back from countless evil practices. Thirteenth, for causing countless wholesome dharmas to enter and give rise to joy. Having faith, one is able to have joy and the seeds.
Such joy, the disciples of the path should rely on four dharmas to practice and fulfill five dharmas.
What are the four dharmas to rely on?
First, relying on the Dharma. Second, relying on desire. Third, relying on further progress. Fourth, relying on solitary sitting, not attached to other desires.
What are the five dharmas fulfilled that are used for the path?
First, for joy, second, for love, third, for reliance, fourth, for pleasure, fifth, for concentration.
Thus, a practitioner of joy can attain the cessation of eight wounds.
What are the eight?

First, the wound of desire, second, the wound of anger, third, the wound of delusion, fourth, the wound of pride, fifth, the wound of craving, sixth, the wound of ignorance, seventh, the wound of gain, respect, and fame, eighth, the wound of doubt and uncertainty.
A practitioner who has already been able to submerge and extinguish these eight wounds will then attain liberation from the world.
Not learning ten dharmas.
What are the ten?

First, not learning right view, second, right conduct, third, right speech, fourth, right action, fifth, right livelihood, sixth, right effort, seventh, right mindfulness, eighth, right concentration, ninth, right liberation, tenth, right wisdom.

By these ten unwholesome dharmas, one encounters straightness through these causes and conditions, and immediately abandons the five kinds of straightness, and follows one of the six kinds of guarding the four bases of mindfulness, without much understanding, one has already abandoned misfortune, not attached to seeking cessation, bodily actions cease, verbal actions cease, mental actions cease, mental considerations are transcended, most excellent transcendence without remainder, having practiced enough is called most excellent.
Virtuous one!

This is what the virtuous one considers, the later mind and consciousness, coming from afar, not creating, not accumulating, not meeting again, then completely ending, this is the cessation of suffering.

The virtuous one listened to the Dharma that was spoken at the beginning, the beginning is also good, the middle is also good, the essential is also good, there is benefit and entry, the most complete purity and the pure essential path, is called the complete beneficial Dharma, the causes and conditions are this.
The beginning was spoken for this reason.
The virtuous Shariputra spoke like this.
The bhikshus received it with utmost sincerity, thinking of what was said like this.
